speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: This is mutiny!

speaker: LT. HARPER
line: No, sir. It's survival.

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: They'll come for us! They're sending help!

speaker: LT. HARPER
line: By the time they get here, it'll be too late. It may already be too late.

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: Don't do this! That's an order!

speaker: SAILOR
line: Lieutenant Harper?

speaker: LT. HARPER
line: Shoot me if you want, Captain Barclay, but I'm not waiting around so I can wind up like the others.

speaker: SAILOR
line: Cast off!

speaker: LISETTE CAPTAIN
line: Hit me.

speaker: LISETTE FIRST MATE
line: It looks like she's just drifting out there.

speaker: LISETTE CAPTAIN
line: Mmmm... we're heading straight for her. This is the Lisette, Canadian fishing vessel CV233, please identify. This is the Lisette, come in please. Cut the engines and meet me up on deck.

speaker: VOICE FROM LIFEBOAT
line: Hello out there. Hey!

speaker: LISETTE CAPTAIN
line: We're throwing you a line. Grab it and we'll pull you in.

speaker: LISETTE CAPTAIN
line: Is everybody all right? Are there any injured?

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully. Thanks for coming.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What was so urgent that you couldn't tell me over the phone?

speaker: MULDER
line: I didn't want to waste any time. A Navy destroyer escort, the USS Ardent, has been missing in the North Atlantic for the past 42 hours.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Missing?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, there's been no radio contact, no distress signals picked up. Search planes and satellites haven't picked up anything either.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're saying that a ship and its entire crew just vanished?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that's what it looked like until last night. A Canadian trawler picked up 18 survivors.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, they must have reported what happened.

speaker: MULDER
line: Only one of those survivors is still alive. He's been taken into the ICU under heavy security.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's wrong with him?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's what I was hoping you could tell me. They won't let me in to see him, but because of your medical background, I was able to get you a clearance code. I want your opinion on this. His name is Harper, Lt. Richard Harper.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, wh...?

speaker: MULDER
line: Meet me back in my office when you're finished. Thank you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me. Is this Lt. Richard Harper?

speaker: NURSE
line: That's what his wristband says.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And he's been positively identified?

speaker: NURSE
line: All military personnel are fingerprinted. Those records were crosschecked at the time of admittance.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, then I think there's been some kind of a mistake here. According to this report, Lt. Harper is 28 years old. Why hasn't a systemic workup been ordered on this patient?

speaker: DR. LASKOS
line: I wasn't aware that my diagnostic decisions required your approval. I'm the physician in charge of this patient. Let me see your clearance.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Can you tell me what's going on here? How can you explain what happened to this man?

speaker: DR. LASKOS
line: This clearance code is invalid. Where'd you get this? Who are you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I am a medical doctor and I would like to see the autopsy reports on the remaining victims.

speaker: DR. LASKOS
line: I haven't got time for this. Give me my patient's chart and leave before I have you removed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Something very strange is going on here, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did they let you in to see Lt. Harper?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, I saw somebody, but whether it was actually the Lieutenant...

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He looked about 90 years old. Off by about half a century. You don't seem too surprised.

speaker: MULDER
line: I want to show you something, Scully. This was the course of the USS Ardent when she disappeared. Now, I've been tracking the points of departure and destination for each of these X-files. On December 12, 1949, a Royal Navy battleship disappeared between Leeds and Cape Perry. The sea was calm, the weather sunny. In 1963, at the height of the Cuban missile crisis, a fleet of Soviet minesweepers left from here for Havana. All 6 vessels vanished without a trace. All in all, I've counted 9 unexplained disappearances. Each of them passed through here - the 65th parallel.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Another Bermuda Triangle?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's more like a wrinkle in time, if Lt. Harper is any indication.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A wrinkle in time? Wh...

speaker: MULDER
line: You know anything about the Philadelphia Experiment?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It was a, uh, a program during World War II to render battleships invisible to radar. But then the Manhattan Project heated up, and it was discontinued and most of the scientists were relocated to Los Alamos.

speaker: MULDER
line: Except none of those scientists ever made it to Los Alamos.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where were they sent?

speaker: MULDER
line: Roswell, New Mexico.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you suggesting that the Philadelphia Experiment used alien technology?

speaker: MULDER
line: Less than nine months after the alleged crash of a UFO in Roswell, New Mexico, the USS Eldridge did more than just hide from radar screens, it disappeared altogether from the Philadelphia Navy Yard only to reappear minutes later, hundreds of miles away, in Norfolk Virginia.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's not possible, Mulder, not without defying all laws of, of time and space.

speaker: MULDER
line: Those physicists may have been trying to manipulate wormholes on Earth.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wormholes?

speaker: MULDER
line: Actual portals where matter interfaces with time at a relatively decelerated or accelerated rate. I'm betting that the military never stopped the work it began 50 years ago.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And that's what you think happened to Lt. Harper?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll find out soon enough. I'M BOOKED ON AN 8:30 flight to Norway.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Have you let Skinner in on this?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm giving myself a 24-hour head start before I give Skinner my report. I want this one myself.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm going with you. If that really was Lt. Harper, I want to know what happened to him.

speaker: NORWEGIAN SKIPPER/SAILOR
line: Nei! Nei! Det er altfor farlig

speaker: MULDER
line: 0 for 5.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What is it, Mulder? Why are they so afraid? My father spent the better part of his life at sea. He had a healthy respect for the ocean, but he never feared it. I see fear in these men's eyes.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Brooklyn couldn't have taken you up there anyway. Your ship has to be classified ice class before it can even go past the Lofoten Basin. My name is Trondheim - Henry Trondheim. The ship you want is the Zehar, a 50-ton trawler with a double hull. It's my ship.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're American.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I was born and raised in Pensacola. I ran a charter business there. I got fed up with tourists.

speaker: MULDER
line: How do you feel about the sea north of Beerenburg?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: This time of year, it'll be 10 hours minimum, each way.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you've been there?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: A few times. A few times I got some of my best hauls out of there.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why is everyone else so afraid to go there?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Well, legends. They grew up on stories.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What stories?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: A huge stone came out of the sky and crashed into the pack ice.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A meteorite?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: An evil god. They worship it by staying away. So... exactly what is it that you're looking for up there?

speaker: MULDER
line: A number of things. How good are you?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: About as good as you're going to get, considering no one else will take you there.

speaker: MULDER
line: When can we leave?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: As soon as we shake on a price.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Feeling any better?

speaker: MULDER
line: Uhhh... You're lucky you inherited your father's legs.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: His sea legs.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's been about 12 hours. You said it was only gonna take 10. What's going on?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I told you before, the visibility is lousy. I've never seen it this thick.

speaker: MULDER
line: How much longer 'til we get there?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Well, we're right where you want to be. I even think we've got what you're looking for. Except one minute it's right in front of us and the next minute it's not. Like something's messing with my radar... and my navigation system. I can't explain it.

speaker: HALVERSON
line: Captain! Pass på!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: We're gonna hit!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Halverson! Check the hull for damage!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I don't get it. This is what you're looking for?

speaker: MULDER
line: The USS Ardent. It's a destroyer escort.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: All right... what do you want with it, anyway? It's a ghost ship. I mean, look at all this corrosion. No one's been aboard this vessel in 20, 30 years.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully. Let's check the crew quarters first.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder. They almost look mummified.

speaker: MULDER
line: Like they've been dead a very long time.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Except for this strange residue.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What was that?

speaker: MULDER
line: An engine.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: My ship!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: No! That's my ship!

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: You're taking my ship!

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Hey! That's my ship!

speaker: HALVERSON
line: Ta det med ro! Trondheim releases Mulder as the Zehar fades away into the fog and darkness.)

speaker: SCULLY
line: Nope.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right. Try it again.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. What is it?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's caked with the same residue that's covering everything.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So we can't even send a distress signal.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: The engine's so corroded down there you can't even... you can't even tell what it is. I've never seen anything like it. Halverson's trying to salvage some parts, but basically what we are is dead in the water.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, the radio's dead too.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Somebody's not telling me what's going on here. Now look, that ship wasn't just my livelihood, that was my life. I have a right to some straight answers.

speaker: MULDER
line: What we're seeing here may be the result of some kind of military experiment.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Military experiment?

speaker: MULDER
line: An artifical time band, where matter moves through time at an accelerated rate.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Tell me in English.

speaker: MULDER
line: Time may be speeding up.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Right. That's almost as crazy as Halverson's "there's a rock that comes down from the sky...".

speaker: MULDER
line: The ship... the ship was launched in 1991. I don't know how else to explain the extent of the corrosion or the decay of the bodies down below.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: You're not buying any of this, are you?

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened?

speaker: SCULLY
line: His skull's been fractured.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Who was that? Halverson!

speaker: MULDER
line: Who are you?

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: Captain Barclay. Commanding officer, USS Ardent.

speaker: MULDER
line: Here you go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Captain Barclay, um, according to your log, shortly after the navigation system failed, several of your crew members saw something in the sea - a growing light.

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: It, it came up through the fog, in the middle of the night. Like it was on fire.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you have any idea what it might have been?

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: Power loss. Everything stopped. Everything. Even the sea. Even the wind. Then the ship, my ship, she began to bleed through the hull near the rivet seams.

speaker: HALVERSON
line: He's a drunkard. He's a drunkard! And he killed Halverson. To hell with him, I don't have to listen to his lies!

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: I'm no liar. It happened, first to some of my men and then to all of them.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened?

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: Time got lost.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's OK, captain. You can take it easy. We're gonna do whatever we can to help you out.

speaker: CAPTAIN BARCLAY
line: What can you do? You can't do anything. I'm 35 years old.

speaker: MULDER
line: There's no way he killed Halverson.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, I'd have to agree with you. That blow that killed Halverson was delivered with considerable strength, and he can't even hold a glass with two hands.

speaker: MULDER
line: That means there's somebody else on board.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: You were a good first mate. You left me alone, and you did your job. It's a shame this had to happen to you so young.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: God vei videre

speaker: MULDER
line: Put it down! Put down the pipe! Put it down!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I could kill you for what you've done.

speaker: MULDER
line: Back off, Trondheim!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: He killed Halverson!

speaker: MULDER
line: He may be our only chance to figure out what happened. Look at him. Look at him! He hasn't aged. Back off!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: His name's Olafsson.

speaker: MULDER
line: You know him?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Everybody in Gildeskal knows him. He's a pirate whaler. He's a wanted criminal. He supplies whales to the Japanese black market. Blues, belugas, sperms.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ask him how he got here.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Hvordan kom du hit?

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Dra til helvete

speaker: MULDER
line: We'll question him later. I don't want to leave Scully alone, in case there are others.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think we found who killed Halverson.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: He'd have killed me too, if it wasn't for Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The ship's log says something about four Norweigian sailors who were picked up when their vessel had sunk.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I guarantee it was Olafsson's men, took my boat and left him stranded there. It's just like these dogs to slit each other's throats.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe we should ask the Captain some more questions.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, Captain Barclay is dead. I don't know how it happened, it was just in the last 15 minutes. It's just like those men below. It's more than rapid aging, Mulder. It's almost as if he's turning into a pillar of salt.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that what this substance is?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it appears to be crystalline, but beyond that...?

speaker: MULDER
line: All right, we're all tired. Let's stow the captain's body and tie up Olafsson so we can all get some rest. I'll take first watch, in case he's not alone.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mmmm. I just fell asleep.

speaker: MULDER
line: You want a few more minutes?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. I'm up.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, what happened to you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Time acceleration is an equation, Mulder, a theory.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then theoretically it's possible. What else could it be?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, whatever it is, it isn't a time warp. None of us has directly observed any of the phenomenon recorded in the ship's log. There is no hard evidence to indicate that this is a time warp.

speaker: MULDER
line: We're the evidence, Scully! Look at us! We're aging by the minute.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, if this is rapid aging phenomena, then why hasn't our hair greyed or started to fall out?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Then what about him, huh? What about him? Why isn't he getting old?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Hvorfor blir du ikke gammel?

speaker: MULDER
line: Relax, relax, Trondheim. Save your energy.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I don't have to listen to you. It's because of you that we got into this.

speaker: MULDER
line: Nobody twisted your arm.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I signed on to bring you here. Not to die.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, what do you know about free radicals?

speaker: MULDER
line: Is this a quiz?

speaker: SCULLY
line: They are highly reactive chemicals containing extra electrons. Now, they can attack DNA proteins, they can cause our body tissue and cell membranes to oxidize.

speaker: MULDER
line: Grow old, you mean?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's the prevailing theory on how our bodies age.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you think something is triggering that reaction in us?

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is just a theory. But what if this ship is drifting towards another massive metallic source, like a meteor. Maybe it's way down deep in the ocean or embedded into an iceberg. But the two could effectively be acting as positive and negative terminals with the ocean itself being a kind of giant battery. That level of electromagnetic energy could be exciting the free radicals and effectively oxidizing every piece of matter in its field.

speaker: MULDER
line: It makes sense, Scully. The organic equivalent to rust would be rapid premature senescence.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: What the hell?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Captain Barclay said the ship was bleeding.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's not blood, Scully. It's rust. Trondheim, you keep an eye on Olafsson.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Where are you going?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder. Where are we going?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not sure yet, but we don't have much time to get there.

speaker: MULDER
line: See this yellow pipe? It's the only one that hasn't corroded through.

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Hei, Trondheim, komme her. Det er noe jeg vil fortelle deg.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Det er ikke noe du kan fortelle meg som jeg er interesserte i.

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Er du sikker? Hvor gikk de andre du, tror du? Og hvorfor tror du de etterlot deg?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Jeg vet hva du prøver å gjøre, Olafsson.

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Hvis du ikke stoler på meg, så stole på de egne øyne. Du så hva som hendte til kapteinen. Det tar bare et par timer. Men du behøver ikke å dø.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Vi må alle dø.

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Ikke på denne måten.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Hvorfor skulle jeg høre på deg? Du er en løgner og en morder.

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Jeg bare drepte gutten for å overleve. Du ville gjøre det samme. Du kan fremdeles gjøre det.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: OK, jeg hører hva du sier. Fortell meg den store hemmeligheten.

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Først la meg gå.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Hvordan vet jeg at du forteller sannheten?

speaker: OLAFSSON
line: Se på meg, Trondheim. Og så, se på deg selv.

speaker: MULDER
line: Olafsson and his men.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why would they hold up here?

speaker: MULDER
line: This is the only drinkable water on the ship. We were both wrong, Scully. It's the water. All the other water's been contaminated.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Contaminated how?

speaker: MULDER
line: Something must have gotten into the desalination tanks where all the ship's potable water is stored. But the water in the sewage system is recycled again and again. It doesn't come from the sea.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, if you're right, then Captain Barclay's drinking binge is what kept him alive.

speaker: MULDER
line: The water from this tank may do the same for us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It doesn't sound like there's very much left.

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened? You were supposed to watch him.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I feel pretty bad about it. I shouldn't have dozed off. Well, what do you want me to say? He's gone, he got away.

speaker: MULDER
line: I want to know what happened?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I can ask the same of you. You're the one that tied him up.

speaker: MULDER
line: There's nothing wrong with my knot! This rope's been severed!

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: I don't like being interrogated. I don't owe you any explanations.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Trondheim!

speaker: MULDER
line: Let go of me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look, we have a lot of work to do here. I'm gonna need blood and urine samples from both of you.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: What for?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We found out what caused the aging.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: What is it now? The two of you are full of theories. First it's one thing, then it's another. By the time you figure out what it is, we'll all be dead.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's the water, Trondheim. Something got into the de-sal tanks, but the water in the sewage system is untainted.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It kept Olafsson alive this long, maybe it will slow the process in us.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: This is good news, isn't it? So what happens now?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It has been 18 hours, 45 minutes since the onset of symptoms. Rudimentary blood tests have revealed impossibly high concentrations of sodium choloride - salt - though the contaminated water itself is not saline. It appears to catalyze existing body fluids, causing massive and rapid cellular damage. The untainted water has slowed the degenerative progression in Trondheim and me, but Mulder has fared less well, perhaps because of the dehydration he suffered on the way here.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think I just lapped George Burns.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'll be right back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: If you've got something to say, say it but don't hover behind me like that.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: The water isn't helping him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then maybe we should double his rations.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: What for? A lake full of water isn't going to bring him back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We don't know that for sure. Not yet.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Look at him! We've wasted too much water on him as it is.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who are you to decide?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: You don't have to be a doctor to see that he isn't gonna make it. But you and me, Scully... you and me... we better start looking out for ourselves.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder's urinalysis continues to indicate his kidneys' failure to excrete the substance I'm calling "heavy salt". Whether the untainted water taken from the sewage system is even helping him at all is unclear. What does remain clear to me is that I can't give up trying.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Trondheim! What are you doing?

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Listen to this. You know what that is? It's a funeral bell. There's only a few gallons left, maybe less.

speaker: SCULLY
line: There's enough to keep us all alive for a few more days.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Or one of us alive long enough to be rescued.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't come any closer.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: What are you gonna do? Shoot me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Trondheim, listen to me. The navy knows where we are. They know these coordinates and they're gonna be here soon. So why don't we just go back up into the mess hall...

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Why don't you just go ahead and shoot me if you think that I'm gonna let Mulder have another drop.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Trondheim! Trondheim!

speaker: MULDER
line: You're almost out of pages. It's good you kept a record.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Trondheim's locked himself in the sewage hold. He's backflushed all the water and he's keeping it for himself. I looked everywhere and this is all I could find. It's sardine juice, half a dozen lemons and uh, the water from a snow globe. It's not Evian, but...

speaker: MULDER
line: You go ahead and drink it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: It's the only logical choice, Scully. You're a woman. Your life expectancy is greater, and your body retains more water in fatty tissues.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's more reason for you to drink it.

speaker: MULDER
line: You have a much greater chance of surviving until help comes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't do this, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Don't be so stubborn, Scully. You know I'm right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, there isn't much liquid to make a difference anyway.

speaker: MULDER
line: There might be.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What was that?

speaker: MULDER
line: The outer hull must have finally corroded through, which means we're taking on water.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... the water.

speaker: TRONDHEIM
line: Uhhh! Can't open the door! Help me! Help me! Help me!

speaker: MULDER
line: I always thought when I got older I'd maybe take a cruise somewhere. This isn't exactly what I had in mind. The service on this ship is terrible, Scully. It's not fair. It's not our time. We still have work to do.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... When they found me, after the doctors and even my family had given up, I experienced something that I never told you about. Even now it's hard to find the words. But there's one thing I'm certain of. As certain as I am of this life, we have nothing to fear when it's over.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm so tired.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You should sleep.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Agent Fox Mulder lost consciousness at nothing more I can do for him, or for myself. Supplies are exhausted, no food or liquid consumed for over 24 hours. The outer hull most probably flooded, though for now the inner hull is supporting the ship's mass. Among Halverson's belongings, I found a children's book of Norse legends. From what I can tell, the pictures show the end of the world - not in a sudden firestorm of damnation as the Bible teaches us, but in a slow covering blanket of snow. First the moon and the stars will be lost in a dense white fog, then the rivers and the lakes and the sea will freeze over. And finally a wolf named Skoll will open his jaws and eat the sun, sending the world into an everlasting night. I think I hear the wolf at the door.

speaker: DR. LASKOS
line: Agent Scully? Agent Scully, can you hear me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mmmm. Yeah.

speaker: DR. LASKOS
line: It's been 36 hours since your rescue. I've got you on dialysis with a high-flux filter. You're obviously responding well. Your electrolytes are almost back to normal and your fluid status has been corrected.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder? Where is he?

speaker: DR. LASKOS
line: His endocrine system was considerably more compromised than yours. Frankly, we didn't think that he'd make it - until we discovered this. Based on your observations, we're giving him a course of synthetic hormones, which seems to be working.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Whatever caused this is still out there. I have to talk to a naval liaison. We have to salvage the ship in order to study the salt...

speaker: DR. LASKOS
line: Agent Scully, the ship was taking on water. It sank less than an hour after you were rescued.
